Entity.title: Entity
Entity.description: The `Entity` is the base of all of types.

Object.title: Object
Object.description: Describes an object of any kind. The `Object` type serves as the base type for most of the other kinds of objects defined in the Activity Vocabulary, including other Core types such as `Activity`, `IntransitiveActivity`, `Collection` and `OrderedCollection`.

Link.title: Link
Link.description: A `Link` is an indirect, qualified reference to a resource identified by a URL. The fundamental model for links is established by [ RFC5988]. Many of the properties defined by the Activity Vocabulary allow values that are either instances of `Object` or `Link`. When a `Link` is used, it establishes a qualified relation connecting the subject (the containing object) to the resource identified by the `href`. Properties of the `Link` are properties of the reference as opposed to properties of the resource.

Activity.title: Activity
Activity.description: An `Activity` is a subtype of `Object` that describes some form of action that may happen, is currently happening, or has already happened. The `Activity` type itself serves as an abstract base type for all types of activities. It is important to note that the `Activity` type itself does not carry any specific semantics about the kind of action being taken.

examples.summary: Sally did something to a note

IntransitiveActivity.title: IntransitiveActivity
IntransitiveActivity.description: Instances of `IntransitiveActivity` are a subtype of `Activity` representing intransitive actions. The `object` property is therefore inappropriate for these activities.

Collection.title: Collection
Collection.description: A `Collection` is a subtype of `Object` that represents ordered or unordered sets of `Object` or `Link` instances. Refer to the Activity Streams 2.0 Core specification for a complete description of the `Collection` type.

OrderedCollection.title: OrderedCollection
OrderedCollection.description: A subtype of `Collection` in which members of the logical collection are assumed to always be strictly ordered.

CollectionPage.title: CollectionPage
CollectionPage.description: Used to represent distinct subsets of items from a `Collection`. Refer to the Activity Streams 2.0 Core for a complete description of the `CollectionPage` object.

OrderedCollectionPage.title: OrderedCollectionPage
OrderedCollectionPage.description: Used to represent ordered subsets of items from an `OrderedCollection`. Refer to the Activity Streams 2.0 Core for a complete description of the `OrderedCollectionPage` object.

Accept.title: Accept
Accept.description: Indicates that the `actor` accepts the `object`. The `target` property can be used in certain circumstances to indicate the context into which the `object` has been accepted.

examples.summary: Sally accepted an invitation to a party
Sally accepted Joe into the club

Add.title: Add
Add.description: Indicates that the `actor` has added the `object` to the `target`. If the `target` property is not explicitly specified, the target would need to be determined implicitly by context. The `origin` can be used to identify the context from which the `object` originated.

examples.summary: Sally added a picture of her cat to her cat picture collection

Announce.title: Announce
Announce.description: Indicates that the `actor` is calling the `target`'s attention the `object`. The `origin` typically has no defined meaning.

examples.summary: Sally announced that she had arrived at work

Arrive.title: Arrive
Arrive.description: An `IntransitiveActivity` that indicates that the `actor` has arrived at the `location`. The `origin` can be used to identify the context from which the `actor` originated. The `target` typically has no defined meaning.

Block.title: Block
Block.description: Indicates that the `actor` is blocking the `object`. Blocking is a stronger form of `Ignore`. The typical use is to support social systems that allow one user to block activities or content of other users. The `target` and `origin` typically have no defined meaning.

Create.title: Create
Create.description: Indicates that the `actor` has created the `object`.

Delete.title: Delete
Delete.description: Indicates that the `actor` has deleted the `object`. If specified, the `origin` indicates the context from which the `object` was deleted.

Flag.title: Flag
Flag.description: Indicates that the `actor` is "flagging" the `object`. Flagging is defined in the sense common to many social platforms as reporting content as being inappropriate for any number of reasons.

Follow.title: Follow
Follow.description: Indicates that the `actor` is "following" the `object`. Following is defined in the sense typically used within Social systems in which the actor is interested in any activity performed by or on the object. The `target` and `origin` typically have no defined meaning.

Ignore.title: Ignore
Ignore.description: Indicates that the `actor` is ignoring the `object`. The `target` and `origin` typically have no defined meaning.

Invite.title: Invite
Invite.description: A specialization of `Offer` in which the `actor` is extending an invitation for the `object` to the `target`.

examples.summary: Sally invited John and Lisa to a party

Join.title: Join
Join.description: Indicates that the `actor` has joined the `object`. The `target` and `origin` typically have no defined meaning.

Leave.title: Leave
Leave.description: Indicates that the `actor` has left the `object`. The `target` and `origin` typically have no meaning.

Like.title: Like
Like.description: Indicates that the `actor` likes, recommends or endorses the `object`. The `target` and `origin` typically have no defined meaning.

Listen.title: Listen
Listen.description: Indicates that the `actor` has listened to the `object`.

examples.summary: Sally listened to a piece of music

Move.title: Move
Move.description: Indicates that the `actor` has moved `object` from `origin` to `target`. If the `origin` or `target` are not specified, either can be determined by context.

examples.summary: Sally moved a post from List A to List B

Offer.title: Offer
Offer.description: Indicates that the `actor` is offering the `object`. If specified, the `target` indicates the entity to which the `object` is being offered.

Question.title: Question
Question.description: Represents a question being asked. Question objects are an extension of `IntransitiveActivity`. That is, the `Question` object is an `Activity`, but the direct object is the question itself and therefore it would not contain an `object` property. Either of the `anyOf` and `oneOf` properties MAY be used to express possible answers, but a Question object MUST NOT have both properties.

Reject.title: Reject
Reject.description: Indicates that the `actor` is rejecting the `object`. The `target` and `origin` typically have no defined meaning.

examples.summary: Sally rejected an invitation to a party

Read.title: Read
Read.description: Indicates that the `actor` has read the `object`.

Remove.title: Remove
Remove.description: Indicates that the `actor` is removing the `object`. If specified, the `origin` indicates the context from which the `object` is being removed.

examples.summary: Sally removed a note from her notes folder
The moderator removed Sally from a group

TentativeReject.title: TentativeReject
TentativeReject.description: A specialization of `Reject` in which the rejection is considered tentative.

examples.summary: Sally tentatively rejected an invitation to a party

TentativeAccept.title: TentativeAccept
TentativeAccept.description: A specialization of `Accept` indicating that the acceptance is tentative.

examples.summary: Sally tentatively accepted an invitation to a party

Travel.title: Travel
Travel.description: Indicates that the `actor` is traveling to `target` from `origin`. `Travel` is an `IntransitiveObject` whose `actor` specifies the direct object. If the `target` or `origin` are not specified, either can be determined by context.

Undo.title: Undo
Undo.description: Indicates that the `actor` is undoing the `object`. In most cases, the `object` will be an `Activity` describing some previously performed action (for instance, a person may have previously "liked" an article but, for whatever reason, might choose to undo that like at some later point in time). The `target` and `origin` typically have no defined meaning.

examples.summary: Sally retracted her offer to John

Update.title: Update
Update.description: Indicates that the `actor` has updated the `object`. Note, however, that this vocabulary does not define a mechanism for describing the actual set of modifications made to `object`. The `target` and `origin` typically have no defined meaning.

View.title: View
View.description: Indicates that the `actor` has viewed the `object`.

object.name: What You Should Know About Activity Streams

Group.title: Group
Group.description: Represents a formal or informal collective of Actors.

Service.title: Service
Service.description: Represents a service of any kind.

Article.title: Article
Article.description: Represents any kind of multi-paragraph written work.

examples.name: What a Crazy Day I Had

Audio.title: Audio
Audio.description: Represents an audio document of any kind.

Document.title: Document
Document.description: Represents a document of any kind.

Image.title: Image
Image.description: Represents an image document of any kind.

Note.title: Note
Note.description: Represents a short written work typically less than a single paragraph in length.

examples.name: A Word of Warning
examples.content: Looks like it is going to rain today. Bring an umbrella!

Place.title: Place
Place.description: Represents a logical or physical location. See 5.3 Representing Places for additional information.

Profile.title: Profile
Profile.description: A `Profile` is a content object that describes another `Object`, typically used to describe `Actor Type` objects. The `describes` property is used to reference the object being described by the profile.

Relationship.title: Relationship
Relationship.description: Describes a relationship between two individuals. The `subject` and `object` properties are used to identify the connected individuals. See 5.2 Representing Relationships Between Entities for additional information.

examples.summary: Sally is an acquaintance of John

Tombstone.title: Tombstone
Tombstone.description: A `Tombstone` represents a content object that has been deleted. It can be used in `Collection`s to signify that there used to be an object at this position, but it has been deleted.

Video.title: Video
Video.description: Represents a video document of any kind.

examples.summary: Mention of Joe by Carrie in her note
examples.name: Joe

id.title: id
id.description: Provides the globally unique identifier for an `Object` or `Link`.

type.title: type
type.description: Identifies the `Object` or `Link` type. Multiple values may be specified.

actor.title: actor
actor.description: Describes one or more entities that either performed or are expected to perform the activity. Any single activity can have multiple `actor`s. The `actor` MAY be specified using an indirect `Link`.

examples.summary: Sally and Joe offered the Foo object

attachment.title: attachment
attachment.description: Identifies a resource attached or related to an object that potentially requires special handling. The intent is to provide a model that is at least semantically similar to attachments in email.

attachment.content: This is what he looks like.

attributedTo.title: attributedTo
attributedTo.description: Identifies one or more entities to which this object is attributed. The attributed entities might not be Actors. For instance, an object might be attributed to the completion of another activity.

audience.title: audience
audience.description: Identifies one or more entities that represent the total population of entities for which the object can considered to be relevant.

examples.name: Holiday announcement
examples.content: Thursday will be a company-wide holiday. Enjoy your day off!

bcc.title: bcc
bcc.description: Identifies one or more Objects that are part of the private secondary audience of this Object.

examples.summary: Sally offered a post to John

bto.title: bto
bto.description: Identifies an Object that is part of the private primary audience of this Object.

examples.summary: Sally offered a post to John

cc.title: cc
cc.description: Identifies an Object that is part of the public secondary audience of this Object.

examples.summary: Sally offered a post to John

context.title: context
context.description: Identifies the context within which the object exists or an activity was performed. The notion of "context" used is intentionally vague. The intended function is to serve as a means of grouping objects and activities that share a common originating context or purpose. An example could be all activities relating to a common project or event.

current.title: current
current.description: In a paged `Collection`, indicates the page that contains the most recently updated member items.

first.title: first
first.description: In a paged `Collection`, indicates the furthest preceeding page of items in the collection.

generator.title: generator
generator.description: Identifies the entity (e.g. an application) that generated the object.

icon.title: icon
icon.description: Indicates an entity that describes an icon for this object. The image should have an aspect ratio of one (horizontal) to one (vertical) and should be suitable for presentation at a small size.

image.title: image
image.description: Indicates an entity that describes an image for this object. Unlike the icon property, there are no aspect ratio or display size limitations assumed.

inReplyTo.title: inReplyTo
inReplyTo.description: Indicates one or more entities for which this object is considered a response.

instrument.title: instrument
instrument.description: Identifies one or more objects used (or to be used) in the completion of an `Activity`.

examples.summary: Sally listened to a piece of music on the Acme Music Service

last.title: last
last.description: In a paged `Collection`, indicates the furthest proceeding page of the collection.

location.title: location
location.description: Indicates one or more physical or logical locations associated with the object.

location.name: Over the Arabian Sea, east of Socotra Island Nature Sanctuary

items.title: items
items.description: Identifies the items contained in a collection. The items might be ordered or unordered.

orderedItems.title: orderedItems
orderedItems.description: Identifies the items contained in a collection. The items are unordered.

oneOf.title: oneOf
oneOf.description: Identifies an exclusive option for a `Question`. Use of `oneOf` implies that the `Question` can have only a single answer. To indicate that a `Question` can have multiple answers, use `anyOf`.

anyOf.title: anyOf
anyOf.description: Identifies an inclusive option for a `Question`. Use of `anyOf` implies that the `Question` can have multiple answers. To indicate that a `Question` can have only one answer, use `oneOf`.

closed.title: closed
closed.description: Indicates that a question has been closed, and answers are no longer accepted.

origin.title: origin
origin.description: Describes an indirect object of the activity from which the activity is directed. The precise meaning of the origin is the object of the English preposition "from". For instance, in the activity "John moved an item to List B from List A", the origin of the activity is "List A".

examples.summary: Sally moved a post from List A to List B

next.title: next
next.description: In a paged `Collection`, indicates the next page of items.

object.title: object
object.description: When used within an `Activity`, describes the direct object of the activity. For instance, in the activity "John added a movie to his wishlist", the object of the activity is the movie added. When used within a `Relationship` describes the entity to which the `subject` is related.

prev.title: prev
prev.description: In a paged `Collection`, identifies the previous page of items.

preview.title: preview
preview.description: Identifies an entity that provides a preview of this object.

result.title: result
result.description: Describes the result of the activity. For instance, if a particular action results in the creation of a new resource, the result property can be used to describe that new resource.

examples.summary: Sally checked that her flight was on time

replies.title: replies
replies.description: Identifies a `Collection` containing objects considered to be responses to this object.

items.content: I am glad to hear it.

tag.title: tag
tag.description: One or more "tags" that have been associated with an objects. A `tag` can be any kind of `Object`. The key difference between `attachment` and `tag` is that the former implies association by inclusion, while the latter implies associated by reference.

target.title: target
target.description: Describes the indirect object, or target, of the activity. The precise meaning of the target is largely dependent on the type of action being described but will often be the object of the English preposition "to". For instance, in the activity "John added a movie to his wishlist", the target of the activity is John's wishlist. An activity can have more than one target.

examples.summary: Sally offered the post to John
Sally offered the post to John

to.title: to
to.description: Identifies an entity considered to be part of the public primary audience of an `Object`.

examples.summary: Sally offered the post to John

url.title: url
url.description: Identifies one or more links to representations of the object.

accuracy.title: accuracy
accuracy.description: Indicates the accuracy of position coordinates on a `Place` objects. Expressed in properties of percentage. e.g. "94.0" means "94.0% accurate".

examples.name: Liu Gu Lu Cun, Pingdu, Qingdao, Shandong, China

altitude.title: altitude
altitude.description: Indicates the altitude of a place. The measurement units is indicated using the `units` property. If `units` is not specified, the default is assumed to be "m" indicating meters.

content.title: content
content.description: The content or textual representation of the `Object` encoded as a JSON string. By default, the value of `content` is HTML. The `mediaType` property can be used in the object to indicate a different content type. The content MAY be expressed using multiple language-tagged values.

examples.content:
## A simple note
A simple markdown `note`

name.title: name
name.description: A simple, human-readable, plain-text name for the object. HTML markup MUST NOT be included. The name MAY be expressed using multiple language-tagged values.

duration.title: duration
duration.description: When the object describes a time-bound resource, such as an audio or video, a meeting, etc, the `duration` property indicates the object's approximate duration. The value MUST be expressed as an `xsd:duration` as defined by [ xmlschema11-2], section 3.3.6 (e.g. a period of 5 seconds is represented as "PT5S").

height.title: height
height.description: On a `Link`, specifies a hint as to the rendering height in device-independent pixels of the linked resource.

href.title: href
href.description: The target resource pointed to by a `Link`

hreflang.title: hreflang
hreflang.description: Hints as to the language used by the target resource. Value MUST be a [BCP47] Language-Tag.

partOf.title: partOf
partOf.description: Identifies the `Collection` to which a `CollectionPage` objects items belong.

mediaType.title: mediaType
mediaType.description: When used on a `Link`, identifies the MIME media type of the referenced resource. When used on an `Object`, identifies the MIME media type of the value of the `content` property. If not specified, the `content` property is assumed to contain text/html content.

endTime.title: endTime
endTime.description: The date and time describing the actual or expected ending time of the object. When used with an `Activity` object, for instance, the `endTime` property specifies the moment the activity concluded or is expected to conclude.

published.title: published
published.description: The date and time at which the object was published

startTime.title: startTime
startTime.description: The date and time describing the actual or expected starting time of the object. When used with an `Activity` object, for instance, the `startTime` property specifies the moment the activity began or is scheduled to begin.

radius.title: radius
radius.description: The radius from the given `latitude` and `longitude` for a `Place`. The units is expressed by the `units` property. If `units` is not specified, the default is assumed to be "m" indicating "meters".

rel.title: rel
rel.description: A link relation associated with a `Link`. The value MUST conform to both the [HTML5] and [RFC5988] "link relation" definitions. In the [HTML5], any string not containing the "space" U+0020, "tab" (U+0009), "LF" (U+000A), "FF" (U+000C), "CR" (U+000D) or "," (U+002C) characters can be used as a valid link relation.

startIndex.title: startIndex
startIndex.description: A non-negative integer value identifying the relative position within the logical view of a strictly ordered collection.

summary.title: summary
summary.description: A natural language summarization of the object encoded as HTML. Multiple language tagged summaries MAY be provided.

totalItems.title: totalItems
totalItems.description: A non-negative integer specifying the total number of objects contained by the logical view of the collection. This number might not reflect the actual number of items serialized within the `Collection` object instance.

units.title: units
units.description: Specifies the measurement units for the `radius` and `altitude` properties on a `Place` object. If not specified, the default is assumed to be "m" for "meters".

updated.title: updated
updated.description: The date and time at which the object was updated

examples.name: Cranberry Sauce Idea
examples.content: Mush it up so it does not have the same shape as the can.

width.title: width
width.description: On a `Link`, specifies a hint as to the rendering width in device-independent pixels of the linked resource.

subject.title: subject
subject.description: On a `Relationship` object, the `subject` property identifies one of the connected individuals. For instance, for a `Relationship` object describing "John is related to Sally", `subject` would refer to John.

examples.summary: Sally is an acquaintance of John's

relationship.title: relationship
relationship.description: On a `Relationship` object, the `relationship` property identifies the kind of relationship that exists between `subject` and `object`.

examples.summary: Sally is an acquaintance of John's

describes.title: describes
describes.description: On a `Profile` object, the `describes` property identifies the object described by the `Profile`.

formerType.title: formerType
formerType.description: On a `Tombstone` object, the `formerType` property identifies the type of the object that was deleted.

deleted.title: deleted
deleted.description: On a `Tombstone` object, the `deleted` property is a timestamp for when the object was deleted.
